awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Who breaked the rule? Rethinking English Past Tense Overregularizations
awd_abstract_narration:
To learn a language, children must go beyond simply imitating speech and learn the rules of the language from their surrounding linguistic environment. One way to tell that children learn rules is that they apply rules to an overly broad set of words. For example, English-learning children produce forms like "breaked" or "catched" at around 3 years of age. These forms, called past tense overregularizations, show that children have implicitly discovered the past tense formation rule: namely, "add -ed to a verb to create the past tense." But does it take children until age 3 to discover such rules? A better understanding of the timeline of rule discovery will help us to develop more realistic milestones to measure children's progress in first language learning. It will also help to us understand why the past tense form is so difficult for second language learners of English and allow more informed pedagogical intervention for these learners.

This work has two goals: the first is to seek evidence that the past tense rule can be found in 16-month-olds, which would be consistent with many observations that children display significant receptive abilities long before their productive abilities reach the same level. The second goal is to determine if the production of past tense overregularizations can be explained by factors other than the discovery of a grammatical rule. There is growing evidence that overregularizations in production reflect children's need to simplify their utterances as they attempt to say more and more complex sentences. Factors that may influence a child's need to simplify utterances are frequency of the lexical item and the child's age. The proposed project will combine a behavioral study with 16-month-olds and a corpus analysis of longitudinal, spontaneous child speech to achieve these goals.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Megan Figueroa has completed research for her dissertation “Who breaked the rule?": Rethinking past tense overregularizations supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. As a scientist interested in the development of language, Figueroa wanted to gain more insight into the language abilities of children and how what we observe children producing is only one metric of children’s language abilities. She was specifically focused on how past tense overregularizations, the well-known language form produced by children learning English–that is, saying “breaked” and “catched” for “broke” and “caught”­–might provide insight into these unseen abilities.

Figueroa accomplished the goal of her research and showed that children have significant receptive abilities long before their productive abilities reach the same level. The data she collected during the grant period strongly suggest children  understand the English past tense rule–add "–ed" to an English verb to create the past tense­–long before they start producing overregularizations. This data provide the foundation for argumentation that decades of research that posit overregularizations in production represent the real-time discovery of the grammatical rule for creating the past tense in English must be reexamined. This research will substantially expand the current debate over the representation of the past tense in English-learning children.

During her grant period, Figueroa traveled to Boston and Madison to present this work at two peer-reviewed conference on child language. This project provided research and work opportunity for two advanced female undergraduate research assistants (RA). One RA was able to attend the Boston conference. This experience was beneficial for the RA as she continues with STEM-related research and scholarship as a now-PhD student. The other RA was able to use the data from this project, which she helped to collect, to start work on her Honor’s thesis. Further, Figueroa is female and a member of an underrepresented minority group and is a first-generation college student, so participation of these three women helps to contribute to the NSF’s dedication to the achievement of societally relevant outcomes, by fostering full participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM-related research.

Figueroa’s research culminated in her dissertation in 2018. This work is a significant contribution to the study of language development because it provides a new starting point for future research on past tense overregularizations in production.


Last Modified: 04/10/2019
Modified by: Megan Figueroa
